content.match_overview: Everton host relegated Ipswich Town in a Premier League dead rubber at Goodison Park. The Toffees (15th, 38pts) have secured safety but endured a poor run of 1 win in 9 matches[1][6], while Ipswich (18th, 21pts) arrive with just 1 victory in 2025 and 12 league defeats[1][4]. Historical context favors Everton who won 2-0 in October's reverse fixture[7], though Ipswich's last Goodison victory came in 2002 under George Burley[6]. Both teams' recent xG trends reveal defensive vulnerabilities - Everton average 1.26 xG against/90 while Ipswich concede 1.84 xG/90[11][12].

citations.description: Match preview with team form analysis

team_news.raw: Everton remain without Dominic Calvert-Lewin (hamstring) and Jesper Lindstrom (ankle), while James Tarkowski faces late fitness test[6]. Ipswich miss Leif Davis (suspension) and Jaden Philogene (knee), but Omari Hutchinson returns from illness[6]. Projected lineups show Moyes sticking with 4-2-3-1 shape, while McKenna opts for defensive 5-3-2[6][8].

home.projected_xi: Pickford; Patterson, Branthwaite, O'Brien, Mykolenko; Gueye, Garner; McNeil, Doucoure, Ndiaye; Broja

away.projected_xi: Palmer; O'Shea, Woolfenden, Burgess, Greaves; Morsy, Taylor; Hutchinson, Enciso, Clarke; Delap

asian_handicap_analysis.analysis: The -1.0 line at 1.89 offers value given Everton's 60.4% win probability[2] vs 52.9% implied probability. While Everton's recent form is poor, they've covered -1 handicap in 50% of home games[4] against teams averaging 1.84 xG against[11]. Ipswich's away xGA of 2.01[11] suggests vulnerability to Everton's set-piece threat (12 set-piece goals conceded)[9].
asian_handicap_analysis.raw: Simulations show 53% probability of Everton winning by 2+ goals[2]. The 1.89 line represents 7.4% value over fair price of 1.75 based on 10k sims[3].

key_player_matchups.title: Jake O'Brien vs Liam Delap
key_player_matchups.content: 6'6" O'Brien dominates aerially (3.1 aerials won/90) vs Delap's 42% duel loss rate[12][11]. Everton's set-piece xG of 0.54/90[12] targets Ipswich's league-high 12 set-piece goals conceded[9].
key_player_matchups.raw: O'Brien's 1.34 xG/set piece[9] could exploit Ipswich's zonal marking issues

key_player_matchups.title: Idrissa Gueye vs Julio Enciso
key_player_matchups.content: Gueye's 2.3 tackles/90[12] faces Enciso's 1.7 dribbles/90[11]. The Senegalese destroyer has neutralized 68% of AMC threats in home games[12].
key_player_matchups.raw: Enciso's 0.18 xA/90[11] may be nullified by Gueye's positioning

betting_insights.insight: Under 2.5 @ 1.96 (51% probability)[2] - Everton average 1.0 goals/90[12], Ipswich 1.1[11]
betting_insights.raw: Last 5 H2Hs average 1.8 goals[7]. Everton's xGA of 1.40 at home[12] supports low-scoring trend

betting_insights.insight: No @ 1.89 (52.9% probability)[2] - Ipswich failed to score in 60% of away games[11]
betting_insights.raw: Everton kept clean sheets in 29% of home games[12] vs Ipswich's 20% away scoring rate[11]

betting_insights.insight: 2-0 Everton @ 7.50 (13% probability)[2] - Aligns with xG projections[5][12]
betting_insights.raw: Simulations show 24% chance of Everton winning by 2+ goals[3]

prediction.reasoning: Everton's defensive solidity (1.40 xGA/home[12]) should contain Ipswich's league-worst attack[11]. Set-piece dominance via O'Brien[9] and Ipswich's travel fatigue (7 away losses[4]) favors comfortable home win.

my_say.content: As Goodison Park prepares for its penultimate Premier League curtain call of the season, this fixture embodies the paradox of dead rubber football - meaningless in the table, yet rich in subtext. For Moyes' Everton, it's a chance to exorcise the ghosts of their late-season collapse against Championship-bound opposition. The towering presence of Jake O'Brien symbolizes their aerial dominance, while Ipswich's kamikaze defending (2.01 xGA/away[11]) offers fertile ground for Beto's physicality. Watch for the 23rd minute - 43% of Everton's goals come between 16-30 minutes[12], a period when Ipswich's concentration historically wanes. This isn't just a relegation sendoff; it's a laboratory for next season's tactical experiments, where Moyes' pragmatism meets McKenna's idealism in what could be a Championship preview for the visitors.
